tweets.content: @wcarrara: How is #opendata and an #open culture being taught at school? Great question around #skills and culture #IODC16 @TheGovLab
@0mgould: .@_karin_c says we should be humble: open data does not fix things, people fix things. OD helps. (isn't education the bedrock?) #iodc16
@Jagusti: Stage layout for #iodc16 education panel literally cuts the guy at the end out of the panel conversation. maybe rearrange for next session?pic.twitter.com/5PXscf9sRt
@KosmiKatarina: 'for decisionmakers open data can be frustrating -data either reveals too little or too much' quoting ex Min of Education in #Serbia #IODC16
@opendatacon: Great number of attendants in Data + Education in Room C running at this moment! #IODC16pic.twitter.com/TN1lW7CpWr
@Jagusti: #iodc16 reflections of the Serbian Education Minister on opening up data: frustrating experience realising govt data often lacks relevancypic.twitter.com/KQRqcBlOIE

conference_notes: This panel gathered four open data experts who presented different perspectives on education and training on open data. Every panelist emphasized the need of educating citizens about data usage. Some of the panelists were focused on guidance and training to participate in public policies and others focused on basic youth education. During this panel, panelists and the public discussed about tools and strategies to include open data in every sectors of the current society as a mechanism to make the most of the public sector information, and relying on citizens to make policies and create new services. The panel, moderated by Marco Túlio (School of Data), had four speakers who presented their perspectives on data education.
name: Data + Education
